column1: In general, an adult who has fewer than 1,000 neutrophils in a microliter of blood has neutropenia.
When the neutrophil count gets this low, even the bacteria normally living in a person's mouth, skin, and gut can cause serious infections.
A person with cancer can get a low white blood cell count from the cancer or from treatment for the cancer.
Cancer may be in the bone marrow, causing fewer neutrophils to be made.
The white blood cell count can also go down when cancer is treated with chemotherapy drugs, which slow bone marrow production of healthy white blood cells.

Other causes of a low white blood cell count include: - Crohn disease - Infections, such as tuberculosis (TB) or certain viruses like HIV - Lupus (also called systemic lupus erythematosus) - Radiation - Rheumatoid arthritis - Some medicines, such as those that treat infections, high blood pressure, or seizures
Prevent infections by taking the following measures: - Be careful with pets and other animals to avoid catching infections from them.
- Wash your hands often with soap and water.
- Stay away from people who have symptoms of an infection
